Reviews.Title: “Hotel with a spirit”
Reviews.Author: Suzen I
Reviews.Content: Every time,when visiting Istanbul, I stay in this hotel.I like very much its atmosfera.The place is great-near to famous Istiklal, and even Mata Hari stayed here.Hotel has historical value.Friendly staff.Nice view to Golden horn from roof bar and most of rooms.

Reviews.Title: “Awful”
Reviews.Author: whalwtab
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for two nights recently and it was awful. I will admit, the lobby is pretty excellent--red velvet curtains and faded wallpaper and talking parrots and chandeliers. But the room was overpriced and smelled like raw sewage. I had a balcony and paid 135 euro a night for this luxury--but there are discos right next door, and pounding music dance played until four in the morning. When I asked to be moved to another room, I was told "Look around you! There are dance clubs on all sides!! All rooms have that noise!!" I asked for a cheaper rate for the second night, because I had a lot of bags and it was too difficult to move for one night. I mentioned that a friend told me he had paid only 70E/night, that the room smelled of sewage, and that the noise was awful. No luck. So, I mentioned that the Hotel Marmara (a beautiful hotel down the street, where I stayed last time) was only 90E per night and could I get a comparable rate? The desk clerk said, "Marmara is only 15 years old!!!! This hotel is 125 years old!!!!' like that made any sense. The door had one flimsy lock on it, and the shower head was broken. There was nowhere to store valuables. My friend paid even more for her room and it reeked of cigarette smoke and sewage. I have traveled all over, and am okay with simple accommodations (stay at Marmara was a business trip....) but this was awful.

Reviews.Title: “Shady hotel, horrible experience”
Reviews.Author: Kleps
Reviews.Content: Grab a drink amid the late Ottoman elegance downstairs, but don't expect any of the warmer aspects of decay to follow you upstairs. Nevermind the peeling wallpaper, cramped space, smell of sewage, or leaky shower, we were awoken every single night at 4 in the morning by slamming doors--draw your own conclusions about who'd be coming in and out, and checking in and out at such an hour on a nightly basis. I caution anyone and everyone from spending the night here. The concierge was somewhat responsive to our complaints, but the few euros he took off the price hardly compensated for lost sleep and overall creepiness.

Reviews.Title: “Great value”
Reviews.Author: CapeTownCurtis
Reviews.Content: This hotel has plenty of fading grandeur, and is a nice place to stay. My wife and I stayed in a perfectly reasonable room for 70 euro's a night, and were more than happy. The hotel is a block away from Istiklal Cadessi, so is very convenient, and the Tunel and hence Sultan Ahmet are close. Breakfast was OK, but not particularly great, and the neighbourhood is noisy (from people having fun), but we were staying there the week of Ramadan, so there were probably more parties than usual. I understand other guests have fussed about the lack of air-con, which seems a bit unnecessary: the fan in the room works well, and mutes the noise. The hotel has a grand view of the Golden Horn from it's top floor, and you can have a very peaceful drink or 2 watching water taxis go back and forth. I thought this hotel was really a pretty good deal, and would be happy to return. The staff were pleasant and helpful. Overall, I found staying rather charming, and I would recommend it to others. At the price, I really think it's a good deal.

Reviews.Title: “Avoid!!!!!! - Read the reviews that rate this hotel as "Terrible" they have it described accurately.”
Reviews.Author: OleDunk
Reviews.Content: I Â have referred to Tripadvisor many times in selecting hotels but I am now having doubts about the reliability of reviews. I am amazed that any one can give this hotel anything other than a very bad review. I checked in and then checked out again 10 minutes later. Read the reviews that rate this hotel as "Terrible" they have it described accurately. Beware!!

Reviews.Title: “service supreme”
Reviews.Author: taxin83
Reviews.Content: From the moment I arrived until the moment I left, the service was impeccable. Starting with the reception at the airport and continuing with the hotel reception. Just imagine, I left a wake up call, and not only was it right on time, but it was followed up by another from the operator and a last one from the hotel manager. I will definitely be back.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent bar, lobby, and staff!”
Reviews.Author: HappyHappyFun
Reviews.Content: The hotel staff -- all of them -- were the most friendly and helpful of any hotel I've every stayed. After a bad experience at Eklektik Guest House in Istanbul, it was refreshing to come here and interact with the staff. The lobby and bar have a great ambiance, plus you're in walking distance of many cafes. The room prices are also unbeatable. Some of the rooms are a bit shabby, but definitely not uncomfortable. We had a problem with the heater and staff immediately accommodated us.

Reviews.Title: “very elegant”
Reviews.Author: pedblan
Reviews.Content: The hotel is very good. During our stay, infra-structure (I highlight the shower) and cleanliness were flawless. Location is good, but it is bad; on the one hand, being in center Beyoglu is very useful to move around the city, and, in addition, it is close to great restaurants; on the other, the hotel is at a busy street, and traffic noise goes on when you are supposed to be relaxing. Other bad bits is the breakfast, which could be larger and more varied, and the wireless internet, which is unstable and slow.

Reviews.Title: “Charme of dereliction!”
Reviews.Author: Kathahata
Reviews.Content: charme of a derelict grand hotel. we had the standard doubleroom for 50 Euros per night and I would say the price is very ok! The Hotel staff is very friendly and courteous. The hotel is situated in the Center of Beyoglu with a walking distance of 5 minutes to the istikal Caddesi, the main shopping street, where lot of nightlife and concerts take place. I d recommend this hotel, it s really charming. Though the matress was worn and torn and a little disgusting..... we slept deep and didnÂ´t here any noise from the street.

Reviews.Title: “Buyuk Londra: Look Beyond History”
Reviews.Author: kathmandusue
Reviews.Content: I have been a regular guest at the Londra Hotel for 25 years. The Londra Hotel has the friendliest staff in all of Istanbul. They go beyond the normal hospitality of a hotel. I was very disappointed to see the reviews stating that the history and grandeur of the Londra has passed. How can history pass? In the hundred plus years of the Londra Hotel the history lives on. Films are made in the lobby along with Turkish soap operas. Famous people come through all the time. Ottoman antiques galore, gorgeous decor, and a view from the terrace of the Golden Horn. Staying at the Londra Hotel gives the traveler a chance to feel what the past was like. If you want a modern hotel, then check into their partner hotel Troya two doors down.

Reviews.Title: “history cannot be the basis for a business”
Reviews.Author: CanuckinBlighty
Reviews.Content: Short story - not worth 150 Euros per night, even with a balcony. They can't continue to rest their laurels on the history of this place carrying them through as a business. The staff were friendly enough but the rooms really let us down - a balcony over a parking lot and the busiest road in Istanbul, not even soap in the bathroom or drinking glassses in the room, an airconditioner over the bed that leaked water on my head during the night, sheets that didn't cover the bed, a worn out mattress that sagged in the middle, lumpy pillows that had been washed too many times, a stained blanket as the top blanket, etc, etc... We stayed in a pension for 50 Euros per night that was much better (views, value and location) and i wish i hadn't booked this as a bday treat for my husband, it certainly wasn't a treat! I have read through the reviews and i think it is interesting that it the higher ratings come from non-British people, I certainly hope they don't think that is the standard for this country!

Reviews.Title: “Option of last resort”
Reviews.Author: NMS77
Reviews.Content: I am a regular visitor to Istanbul, and booked into the Buyuk Londra because my usual hotels were full. It's not that the Buyuk Londra is terrible, it's just that it is still trading on its former glories, and you could get a lot better value for your money. Avoid the old unrenovated rooms at all costs. These are likely to be dirtier (especially the bathrooms), even if you don't mind being without aircon. The new rooms are better, but still make sure your room has been cleaned properly. Of course, the faded grandeur is fun, as is the talkative parrot in the foyer. The location is excellent, and the rooftop terrace bar is a lovely place to watch the sun set. However, one balance there is a lot better out there.

Reviews.Title: “Istanbul in the 19th century”
Reviews.Author: Benodon
Reviews.Content: Great place, lots of old furniture, in the middle of the action and not too expensive. Rooms are small but descent. However I wouldnâ€™t recommend staying too long. Ideal hotel for a weekend in Istanbul

Reviews.Title: “this place had his best days already ....”
Reviews.Author: slaritbartfass999
Reviews.Content: I loved this hotel for many years but since it became popular because of some movies they bare megalomanic. It`s a old shabby hotel - because of this I liked it ( meanwhile some rooms are renovated , and the service is very bad and unfriendly ( beware to give something to the laundry - they rip you off ). Anyway, I liked it because it was so old and special - but for their new rates you can find something better. The breakfast is in a room situated in the cellar and really lousy - better miss it !

Reviews.Title: “Grand Hotel de Londres”
Reviews.Author: ReasonLondon
Reviews.Content: I booked to stay here for six nights from 28th April to 4th May and reserved one of their larger corner rooms (103). This contained a double and single bed, a writing table and another table, ample storage space and a decent sized bathroom with good shower cubicle. Need to run the water for a while though before it runs hot. The A/C worked fine as did the TV. I paid 120 Euros per night, which I thought was good value for a large room facing over the distant Golden Horn. There was an old mat in the bathroom, which needs replacing, but this is the only criticism I would make. Didn't try the breakfast, so can't comment. The bars are both good, with the roof terrace having fantastic views. The downstairs bar is just wonderful with its two parrots and juke box and the prices are decent by hotel standards - 2.5 TL for a tea and 6 TL for a beer. There is a laptop for guests' use free of charge as well. I only got on it a couple of times. They could do with another. The location is fantastic, but the road can be very noisy at times (even through double glazing) thanks to the propensity of Istanbuli drivers' need to hoot at the slightest opportunity. Luckily I had my ear plugs handy. Would I stay again. Yes, but probably from Sunday to Thursday to avoid the noisiest nights from the traffic. Also, Istiklal Caddesi is a little less crowded then.

Reviews.Title: “my kind of hotel”
Reviews.Content: Old-fashioned establishment with style and class. Great staff as well. Breakfast not worth the trouble. If you like a hotel that turns the time clock backwards, bÃ¼yÃ¼k hotel londres is the place for you. Don't hesitate. They also upgraded us, just like that - and that didn't hurt. And the location, right off Istiklal, in the night-time part of town, is equally excellent. If you decide not to stay there, at least go there for drinks. The lobby is a special place. And the parrots are a riot.

Reviews.Title: “A relief from modern blandness - if you have a sense of humour”
Reviews.Author: Tim_Millea
Reviews.Content: Firstly, not related to the hotel but in my journey to it, I must give a warning about Istanbul taxi drivers. I have visited Turkey dozens of times over the years and have been ripped off as least as many times. I think there is something about being English which, even when knowing that we are being ripped off, we still go along with it then whinge about it later. I had intended walking to the hotel but the rain started about 2 minutes after the Havas airport bus dropped me at Taksim Square. Just a spot at first and then heavier and heavier. I found a waiting taxi and gave him the directions in Turkish from the hotel website. The driver told me that traffic was a "big problem" when it rains and we had to go a longer route. When I was asked if this was my first time in Istanbul the warning bell sounded. He eventually dropped me well short of the hotel. Instead of the expected 5-10 Lira, the fare was 28 Lira. I protested but he pointed to his meter and it clearly said 28. I realised I had been had but I didn't want to risk violence or look mean and there was always an outside chance that the meter was right and his tale of avoiding the rain traffic was true. I gave him two 20 Lira notes. He turned away then straight back to me and said "twenty-eight". He was now holding a 20 and a 5. Then, I assumed it was my mistake. I apologised took the 5 off him and gave him another 20. His downfall was that he repeated the same trick again - "twenty eight!". I did a quick calculation, managed to snatch the one 20 note he was holding, explained to him politely that I thought him a crazy theif and made my escape. Still, he managed to obtain a net 35 lira from me for a 5-10 lira journey. Beware! To the hotel. While many reviewers mention its faded elegance, few mention how small the hotel is. There are just 12 rooms per floor giving a total of 48 rooms. I have seen five staff on duty at any one time including the chef in the kitchen (who I sought one morning to ask if it were possible to have some coffee in the coffee - he looked surprised but I have since noticed that he looks permanently surprised) and the very charming chamber maid (who doesn't speak a word of English - and perhaps not of Turkish either). I suspect the name 'Grand' must always have been at least a little tongue in cheek. It reminds me of the cinema of the same name in the Peter Sellers film "The Smallest Show on Earth". Most of the double-height ground floor is occupied by the splendid bar (just as it appears in the hotel website photos) although it has lost all of the caged birds mentioned elsewhere. Otherwise there is just a hallway from the front door with a 'one person' reception, and a tiny, but significant lift ('elevator' in US English) off. The end of the hallway turns into a very cosy second bar under the stairs which I have not seen open. It may not be economically viable to operate such a small bar. Breakfast is served in the basement which features windows with fluorescent light tubes behind for that 'always daytime' effect. The breakfast is Turkish, i.e. continental plus olives, sliced cucumber and tomato, cake and Turkish tea. The rooftop bar was closed during my stay but I can testify that the view over old Istanbul across the water is superb. The rooms at the front of the hotel (x01, x02, x03 and possibly x04) must have similar views and also, to the left, of the the hotel we would all be staying in if we could have afforded it - the Pera Palace. My room is a rather small single, about one and a half single beds long by two single beds wide (i.e. approximately 9 feet by 6 feet). The ceiling height is certainly greater than the width of the room and, curiously, the door is around two-feet taller than the length of the bed. I assume this room was originally intended for single giants who like to sleep with their feet out of the window. However, the worst aspect of the room, and the other room 12's below it, is that they are next door to the only lift. It is not just the usual issue of hearing people get in and out of the lift with a clanging, hinged metal door, but that the deep buzzing sound of the lift operating pervades the whole room and seems to make my brain resonate. The dividing wall vibrates as do two of the light fittings. Each time the lift starts up it feels and sounds like the occupants of the neighbouring room have fired a photon torpedo. The effect of the lift stopping is even harder to describe - something like being hit by a photon torpedo. Rooms 112, 212, 312, and 412 are probably best avoided, unless this is your type of thing. The receptionist asked when I was checking-in whether I had been to the hotel before. It may be part of the hotel's collective sense of humour to allocate these rooms to unsuspecting, 'virgin' guests. I have a tiled shower room with barely space to turn around, no shower curtain or tray just a drain in the floor. There were also a few ants on the bathroom floor but none have reappeared since I expelled them to the ground below my window. I imagine it will take them a few days to travel back, even walking briskly. The walls of the room are wallpapered with an 1930's reproduction, embossed art-deco wall paper in tobacco brown. I know that it is reproduction because it has been applied with only the lack of skill that a modern amateur could possess. The curtains are co-ordinated in a similar shade of tobacco. The carpet is a faded red colour with a huge green and brown leaf pattern - again fitted without without compromise to any degree of professionalism. There are some fraying rough-cut edges and the occasional lump under foot. There is a small, free standing single wardrobe, just large enough for the bellboy to hide in, thankfully it features a door that doesn't close. There are also half a dozen hangers sponsored by Karecelik Dry Cleaners. Above the wardrobe is an antique, 12" cathode ray tube television mounted on a wall bracket. I haven't tried this for fear of annoying the occupants of the lift. The bed is single with the headboard right next to the door. Consequently, it is possible not only to hear people leaving and entering their rooms but, after a few days, to determine exactly which room they are leaving or entering and to construct their whole life stories from their conversations outside the lift. There are no tea and coffee making facilities, but the chamber maid boils a huge kettle in the corridor immediately outside my doorway several times a day. I had brought my own cup and coffee on spec. When I asked her nicely, she let me have some boiling water. I think she likes me. Prices in the bar are very reasonable by Istanbul hotel standards - a glass of wine cost me 6 Lira, around Â£2.80 or â‚¬3 at current exchange rates. There is no price list however - the only way of knowing bar prices in advance would be to ask the bar man. I think he liked me too, so don't be shocked if the bar prices you pay are not quite as reasonable as this. On my second day the rain still had not stopped so I asked the receptionist if I could borrow an umbrella. Sadly none were available. However, an umbrella salesman magically appeared just outside the hotel selling disposable, polythene umbrellas. At 10 Lira each, I chose to get wet. Others have mentioned the excellent location and I must agree. Beside being a two minute walk from the pedestrianised section of Istikal Street which in the evening is unbelievably packed with shoppers, promenaders, musicians, street entertainers, charming touts and skilled pickpockets. It is only slighter further away from the new Sishane metro station. The main entrance is on the same street as the hotel, around 200m down the hill past the Pera Palace. I feel a longing pain as I pass that hotel. I was here to attend a conference at Istanbul Technical University, which has its own station 20 minutes the opposite way. Trains run approximately every 10 minutes. It is currently necessary to change at Taksim square as the line to/from Sishane is operated as a single track shuttle. For those trying to pinpoint the hotel on Google Maps, it is opposite and facing the large TRT Studios building on Mesrutiyet Cad. one building down from the corner with Kallavi Sokak. On satellite view, the Grand Hotel de Londres is in a dark shadow extending little further than the hotel. Choose this hotel for its location, its elegant bar, old fashioned values, a latent sense of humour and moodestly concealed elegance. The economy rooms are very economical by Istanbul standards but be warned that the singles are best used only for sleeping in and only then when everyone else has gone to bed.

Reviews.Title: “Mixed review, but will return”
Reviews.Author: BuieKnife
Reviews.Content: We stayed for 6 nights in September in an unrenovated room. The Negatives Like other reviewers, we found that category of room to be a bit tough. The first night I was placed next to a club with resounding music, so I requested a switch. The unrenovated rooms are rather dismal, with plenty of holes in the sheets and about the smallest bathrooms I've experienced in fairly wide travels. Also, the breakfast was pretty much the same, day in and day out, so that got boring. The rooftop restaurant had lovely views, but the staff seemed to be out hunting, butchering, and finally preparing our dinner, at long last, with a few "Hallo"s from us as beards grew and hairs whitened and children entered adolescence. The Positives The atmosphere, the bar, the talking parrots are a kick! The location is unbeatable - out the front door, hang a left, and before you know it, you're on Istiklal Caddesi! The manager was incomparable in his knowledge and in his helpfulness in making arrangments. So were one of the breakfast servers. We would certainly stay again, despite the drawbacks, because of the hotel's quirky history/appearance/cast of characters/location.

Reviews.Title: “Quirky, fun and amazing breakfast!”
Reviews.Author: fksNYC
Reviews.Content: I stayed here at the recommendation of a Turkish friend who lists the Buyuk Londra as a favorite when she returns home to Istanbul. The location is ideal--one block from the busy main street in Beyoglu--and the area is safe, quiet but you're able to be in the mix of things in a couple of steps. All the staff went out of their way to help us--upgraded us to a bigger room for no extra charge, helped us with directions, called us a cab to the airport (and talked to the driver to make sure he didn't overcharge us)--and were so friendly and welcoming. Lobby and bar were my favorite part: There is so much history and quirky decorations in the Hotel Londra! You feel like you just stepped off the Orient Express. I could have spent a day just looking at photos and antiques here (not to mention the talking caged parrots!) The breakfast spread is reason alone to stay here and probaby saved us $10 per day each. Delicious spread of breads, cheeses, olives, eggs, cereal, coffee, teas, etc. Not your traditional mediocre continental breakfast (although maybe it was traditional by Turkish standards!) Rooms were clean, if small, and not particularly fancy, although we opted for a cheaper unrenovated room. I'd much prefer the charm and character of the Londra compared to the impersonal genericness of larger hotel chains!!

Reviews.Title: “Very special place”
Reviews.Author: sm255
Reviews.Content: I have been staying at the good old Buyuk Londra for ten years, on frequent trips to Turkey. I think that either you like this sort of thing, or you don't; it's very quirky and different and this pleases me so much that I don't mind the lack of a/c or the unfancy bedrooms. The location is fabulous - you are right next to Istiklal Caddesi and its passages and alleys, and in the heart of the vibrant Beyoglu district. This is where Turkish people come to play, and watching the passegiata in the cool evenings on the old Grand Rue de Pera is a wonderful experience. A merciful escape from the tourists and touts of Sultanahmet, life in Beyoglu is real Istanbul.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel in a shape of musseum”
Reviews.Author: Nixondorollo
Reviews.Content: When we booked our trip in May, Istanbul was on our top list in Turkey. Buyuk Londra Hotel looks amazing on the pictures but when it comes to service and room sizes, it is a big dissapointment. However it's central location in town is a big plus, since in Istanbul, you do not need to spend that much time in your room, but more on the roads.

Reviews.Title: “Unachieved Potential”
Reviews.Author: zippo75
Reviews.Content: If your stay in the hotel doesn't take you past you past the bar, you're in luck! The bar and lounge are charming indeed. You can see (and smell) the glorious past of the hotel. That was the extent of the hotel's charm. Upon check-in, the hotel had somehow lost all of our reservations. They pulled together a couple of rooms (after one of us had to wait for two hours). The room (unrenovated) was horrible. Cigarette burns on the bedspread, the sheets did not smell or feel clean, and the bathroom was simply disgusting. It's too bad. The hotel is indeed charming---but if cleanliness and minimal comfort are important for your---it misses the mark.

Reviews.Title: “Love it!”
Reviews.Author: PrincessJosephine
Reviews.Content: Love this place! It is a charming old hotel, featured in several films by Fatih Akin (Gegen die Wand and Crossing the Bridge) but looks much better now after renovations. The staff are friendly and service is professional. The bed was so comfy I almost didn't want to get up. I have stayed here twice and it has become my home when I spend the weekend in Istanbul. Breakfast Buffet is great too!

Reviews.Title: “Do you want luxury and comfort, or a great experience?”
Reviews.Author: rob7565
Reviews.Content: after reading the two most recent reviews, I was a little upset. This hotel was my home for 3 weeks and I have never had a better experience. But then again, what do you go to a hotel for? 100% comfort or the experience? I was studying abroad in Berlin and Istanbul was a side-trip. Our professor had stayed at the Londra a decade previous. Given she had been in contact with them for our booking, she walked in and they greeted her as if she were a close friend they had not seen since her last stay. Immediately, the twelve of us felt at home. We were split into 3 different rooms. I can assure you they were not renovated. We did have a few minor problems with plumbing, but I think it's mostly people not being pampered as they feel they should be on a vacation. It was cold, rainy and snowy during our entire stay, but the view was mesmerizing. You're in a foreign place, why not feel as if you are in an environment that fits your location, rather than a modern, newly built escape from the rich culture around you? The street behind is one of the most famous strips of nightclubs, restaurants and shopping in the world, leading to Taksim Square. Why would you want to escape this? For the majority of us, Istanbul is not a place you will frequently visit unless your business calls for it or you realize how amazing of a city it is and decide to reside there. However, if I do ever have the chance to return, the Londra will be my choice. Why? Because when I walk in, I will tell them about my stay there x-number of years ago, and they will be interested and excited..then, I will take whatever I'm working on to a chair next to the bar and the birds, and order a glass of Raki. To those who complained about the "smokiness," aren't the majority of places in Europe smoke filled? If you can't stand it, don't go to Europe, or go in the warm months so you can spend your time outdoors.

HotelInfo.Name: Grand Hotel de Londres
HotelInfo.Address: Mesrutiyet Cad. | No:53 Tepebasi, Beyoglu, Istanbul 80050, Turkey
